The **economy of Burkina Faso** is based primarily on subsistence farming and
livestock raising. Burkina Faso has an average income purchasing-power-parity
per capita of $1,900 and nominal per capita of $790 in 2014. More than 80% of
the population relies on subsistence agriculture with only a small fraction
directly involved in industry and services. Highly variable rainfall, poor
soils, lack of adequate communications and other infrastructure, a low
literacy rate, and a stagnant economy are all longstanding problems of this
landlocked country. The export economy also remained subject to fluctuations
in world prices.

The country has a high population density, few natural resources, and a
fragile soil. Industry remains dominated by unprofitable government-controlled
corporations.[_citation needed_] Following the African franc currency
devaluation in January 1994 the government updated its development program in
conjunction with international agencies, and exports and economic growth have
increased. Maintenance of its macroeconomic progress depends on continued low
inflation, reduction in the trade deficit, and reforms designed to encourage
private investment.

The Burkinabé financial system represents 30% of the country's GDP and is
dominated by the banking sector, which accounts for 90% of total financial
system assets. Eleven banks and five non-bank financial institutions operate
in the country.

The banking sector is highly concentrated, with the three largest banks
holding nearly 60% of total financial sector assets. Banks are generally
adequately capitalized, but remain vulnerable due to their overexposure to the
cotton sector, the prices of which are subject to significant oscillations.

A December 2018 report from the World Bank indicates that cotton had become
the most important cash crop, while gold exports were increasing in recent
years. In 2017, economic growth increased to 6.4% in 2017 (vs. 5.9% in 2016)
primarily due to gold production and increased investment in infrastructure.
The increase in consumption linked to growth of the wage bill also supported
economic growth. Inflation remained low, 0.4% that year but the public deficit
grew to 7.7% of GDP (vs. 3.5% in 2016). The government was continuing to get
financial aid and loans to finance the debt. To finance the public deficit,
the Government combined concessional aid and borrowing on the regional market.
The World Bank said that the economic outlook remained favorable in the short
and medium term, although that could be negatively impacted. Risks included
high oil prices (imports), lower prices of gold and cotton (exports) as well
as terrorist threat and labour strikes.
openai_summarised_points: • The economy of Burkina Faso is primarily based on subsistence farming and livestock raising, reflecting the country's reliance on agriculture for livelihoods.
• In 2014, Burkina Faso's average income based on purchasing-power-parity (PPP) per capita was $1,900, while the nominal per capita income was $790.
• Over 80% of the population depends on subsistence agriculture, with only a small fraction engaged directly in industry and services sectors.
• The country faces longstanding economic challenges including highly variable rainfall, poor soils, inadequate communications and infrastructure, a low literacy rate, and a stagnant economy.
• Burkina Faso's economy is vulnerable to fluctuations in world prices due to its reliance on exports.
• The country has a high population density, limited natural resources, and fragile soil conditions, which constrain economic development.
• Industry in Burkina Faso remains dominated by unprofitable government-controlled corporations, indicating limited private sector growth.

• Following the devaluation of the African franc in January 1994, the government revised its development program in collaboration with international agencies, leading to increased exports and economic growth.
• Sustaining macroeconomic progress depends on maintaining low inflation, reducing the trade deficit, and implementing reforms to promote private investment.

• The financial system of Burkina Faso accounts for approximately 30% of the country's GDP and is predominantly centered around the banking sector, which makes up 90% of total financial system assets.
• There are eleven banks and five non-bank financial institutions operating within the country.
• The banking sector is highly concentrated, with the three largest banks controlling nearly 60% of total financial sector assets.
• Banks are generally well-capitalized but remain vulnerable due to overexposure to the cotton sector, whose prices are highly volatile.
• A December 2018 World Bank report indicated that cotton had become the most important cash crop in Burkina Faso, with gold exports increasing in recent years.
• In 2017, Burkina Faso experienced an economic growth rate of 6.4%, up from 5.9% in 2016, primarily driven by gold production and increased infrastructure investment.
• Growth was also supported by increased consumption linked to the expansion of the wage bill.
• Inflation remained low at 0.4% in 2017, but the public deficit widened to 7.7% of GDP from 3.5% in 2016.
• The government continued to receive financial aid and loans to finance its debt and public deficit.
• To finance the deficit, the government combined concessional aid with borrowing on regional markets.

• The World Bank's outlook for Burkina Faso's economy remained favorable in the short and medium term, though risks such as high oil prices (affecting imports), lower gold and cotton prices (affecting exports), terrorism, and labor strikes could negatively impact growth.

Gross Domestic Product of Burkina Faso at market prices estimated by the International Monetary Fund with figures in millions of CFA Francs.  Year | Gross Domestic Product | US Dollar Exchange | Inflation Index (2000=100)
---|---|---|---
1980 | 412,240 | 211.29 CFA Francs | 45
1985 | 642,387 | 449.22 CFA Francs | 67
1990 | 848,910 | 272.26 CFA Francs | 65
1995 | 1,330,159 | 499.12 CFA Francs | 88
2000 | 1,861,522 | 711.86 CFA Francs | 100
2005 | 3,027,196 | 526.56 CFA Francs | 115

For purchasing power parity comparisons, the US Dollar is exchanged at 470.70
CFA Francs only. Mean wages were $0.56 per man-hour in 2009.

Burkinabé exports in 2006

Current GDP per capita of Burkina Faso grew 13% in the Sixties reaching a peak
growth of 237% in the Seventies. But this proved unsustainable and growth
consequently scaled back to 23% in the Eighties. Finally, it shrank by 37% in
the Nineties. Average wages in 2007 hover around 2 to 3 dollars per day.

Although disadvantaged by an extremely resource-deprived domestic economy,
Burkina Faso remains committed to the structural adjustment program it
launched in 1991. It has largely recovered from the devaluation of the CFA in
January 1994, with a 1996 growth rate of 5.9%.

Many Burkinabé migrate to neighbouring countries for work, and their
remittances provide a substantial contribution to the balance of payments.
Burkina Faso is attempting to improve the economy by developing its mineral
resources, improving its infrastructure, making its agricultural and livestock
sectors more productive and competitive, and stabilizing the supplies and
prices of cereals.

The agricultural economy remains highly vulnerable to fluctuations in
rainfall. The Mossi Plateau in north central Burkina Faso faces encroachment
from the Sahara. The resultant southward migration means heightened
competition for control of very limited water resources south of the Mossi
Plateau. Most of the population ekes out a living as subsistence farmers,
living with problems of climate, soil erosion, and rudimentary technology. The
staple crops are pearl millet, sorghum, maize, and rice. The cash crops are
cotton, groundnuts, karite (shea nuts), and sesame. Livestock, once a major
export, has declined.

A 2018 report by the African Development Bank Group discussed a macroeconomic
evolution: "higher investment and continued spending on social services and
security that will add to the budget deficit". This group's prediction for
2018 indicated that the budget deficit would be reduced to 4.8% of GDP in 2018
and to 2.9% in 2019. Public debt associated with the National Economic and
Social Development Plan was estimated at 36.9% of GDP in 2017.
openai_summarised_points: • The Gross Domestic Product (GDP) of Burkina Faso at market prices, estimated by the International Monetary Fund, is provided in millions of CFA Francs for the years 1980, 1985, 1990, 1995, 2000, and 2005, with corresponding figures of 412,240; 642,387; 848,910; 1,330,159; 1,861,522; and 3,027,196 CFA Francs respectively.

• The US dollar exchange rate for these years was 211.29 CFA Francs in 1980, 449.22 CFA Francs in 1985, 272.26 CFA Francs in 1990, 499.12 CFA Francs in 1995, 711.86 CFA Francs in 2000, and 526.56 CFA Francs in 2005.
• For purchasing power parity (PPP) comparisons, the US dollar is exchanged at a rate of 470.70 CFA Francs.
• Mean wages in Burkina Faso were approximately $0.56 per man-hour in 2009.
• Burkina Faso's GDP per capita experienced a 13% growth during the 1960s, peaked with a 237% increase in the 1970s, then declined by 23% in the 1980s, and shrank by 37% in the 1990s.
• Average wages in 2007 ranged between $2 and $3 per day.
• Despite a resource-deprived domestic economy, Burkina Faso has remained committed to the structural adjustment program initiated in 1991.
• The country largely recovered from the CFA devaluation in January 1994, achieving a GDP growth rate of 5.9% in 1996.
• Many Burkinabé migrate to neighboring countries for work, with remittances making a significant contribution to the nation's balance of payments.

• Efforts to improve the economy include developing mineral resources, enhancing infrastructure, increasing productivity and competitiveness in agriculture and livestock sectors, and stabilizing cereal supplies and prices.
• The agricultural sector remains highly vulnerable to rainfall fluctuations, with the Mossi Plateau in north-central Burkina Faso facing encroachment from the Sahara Desert.
• Southward migration due to desert encroachment leads to increased competition for limited water resources south of the Mossi Plateau.
• Most of the population are subsistence farmers facing challenges such as climate variability, soil erosion, and rudimentary technology.
• Staple crops include pearl millet, sorghum, maize, and rice; cash crops include cotton, groundnuts, shea nuts (karite), and sesame.
• Livestock, once a major export commodity, has declined significantly.

• A 2018 report by the African Development Bank Group highlighted macroeconomic trends, noting that higher investment and continued spending on social services and security would increase the budget deficit.
• The 2018 prediction indicated the budget deficit would decrease to 4.8% of GDP in 2018 and further to 2.9% in 2019.
• Public debt related to the National Economic and Social Development Plan was estimated at 36.9% of GDP in 2017.
• In 2018, Burkina Faso produced approximately 1.9 million tons of sorghum, making it a significant staple crop for the country.
• The country also produced around 1.7 million tons of maize, indicating its importance as a primary food crop.
• Millet production in 2018 reached approximately 1.1 million tons, contributing to local diets and agriculture.
• Burkina Faso produced about 630 thousand tons of cowpeas in 2018, ranking it as the third-largest producer globally, behind Niger and Nigeria.
• Sugar cane production was approximately 490 thousand tons, supporting both domestic consumption and processing industries.
• Cotton production in 2018 totaled around 482 thousand tons, serving as a key cash crop for farmers and the textile sector.
• The country produced approximately 329 thousand tons of peanuts, which are important for both domestic use and export.
• Sesame seed production was about 253 thousand tons in 2018, making Burkina Faso the eighth-largest producer worldwide.
• Vegetable production reached approximately 240 thousand tons, contributing to local food security and markets.
• Rice production was around 160 thousand tons, supporting national consumption and rural livelihoods.
• Cashew nut production was approximately 103 thousand tons, positioning Burkina Faso as the 12th-largest producer globally.
• In addition to these major crops, Burkina Faso produced smaller quantities of various other agricultural products, indicating a diverse agricultural sector.

text:
Industry, still in an embryonic stage, is located primarily in Bobo-Dioulasso,
Ouagadougou, Banfora, and Koudougou. Manufacturing is limited to food
processing, textiles, and other import substitution heavily protected by
tariffs. Some factories are privately owned, and others are set to be
privatized. Burkina Faso's exploitable natural resources are limited, although
a manganese ore deposit is located in the remote northeast. Gold mining has
increased greatly since the mid-1980s and, along with cotton, is a leading
export moneyearner. However, both gold and cotton are listed as goods produced
mostly by child labor and forced labor according to a recent U.S. Department
of Labor report.
openai_summarised_points: • The industrial sector of Burkina Faso remains in an embryonic stage, with primary activity concentrated in the cities of Bobo-Dioulasso, Ouagadougou, Banfora, and Koudougou.
• Manufacturing activities are limited mainly to food processing, textiles, and other import substitution industries that are heavily protected by tariffs.
• The manufacturing sector includes both privately owned factories and enterprises that are scheduled for privatization.
• Burkina Faso's natural resources are limited; however, there is a manganese ore deposit located in the remote northeast region of the country.
• Gold mining has experienced significant growth since the mid-1980s, becoming a major contributor to the country's exports alongside cotton.

• Gold and cotton are the leading export commodities of Burkina Faso, but both are reported to be produced predominantly using child labor and forced labor, as indicated in a recent report by the U.S. Department of Labor.

text:
According to the United States Department of Labor in 2012, 37.8% of children
in Burkina Faso aged 5-14 were working, while another 13.6% were both going to
school and working.

Children working in granite quarries and gold mines were working 6 to 7 days a
week for up to 14 hours per day. So-called "payment" is in the form of food to
eat and a place to sleep. Since that time, the government has adopted a
National Action Plan, and in collaboration with Interpol, have since have
rescued many children from child trafficking.

By 2023, the percentage of children working in Burkina Faso had dropped
slightly to 35.7%, according to the United States' Department of Labor.

Christian Children's Fund of Canada (CCFC) has partnered with EDUCO, a fellow
member of the ChildFund Alliance, to implement a European Union-funded project
in north Burkina to prevent children from working in mines.
